summary:
Aarti Gupta is Professor of Global Environmental Governance with the Environmental Policy Group, Department of Social Sciences, Wageningen University, the Netherlands. Her research is in the field of global environmental and climate governance, with a focus on transparency and accountability in governance, and the challenges of anticipatory governance of novel technologies (including biotechnology and climate engineering). She has published widely on these topics, including Transparency in Global Environmental Governance: Critical Perspectives (2014, MIT Press). 

At Wageningen University’s Environmental Policy Group, Aarti coordinates the ‘Governing Climate Futures’ research theme. She is the principal investigator of ‘The Transformative Potential of Climate Transparency’ (TRANSGOV) project, funded by the Netherlands Organization for Research. She also co-leads the international REIMAGINE consortium project on anticipatory climate governance in vulnerable regions of the global South. She is a co-founder of the university-wide interdisciplinary REDD@WUR network consisting of over 80 researchers working on climate-forest interactions.

Internationally, she is a member of the Scientific Steering Committee of the Earth System Governance (ESG) research alliance, the largest network of social scientists working on sustainability, and a Coordinating Lead Author of the 2018 ESG Science Plan. She is Series Co-editor of the Cambridge Elements in Earth System Governance series (CUP), and was Associate Editor of the journal Global Environmental Politics (MIT Press) from 2012-2020. She has also been a member of the Academic Working Group on Climate Engineering Governance, and Vice-Chair of an EU COST Action on Transformations in Global Environmental Governance.

She holds a PhD from Yale University, with a background in political science, international relations, and science and technology studies. Prior to moving to the Netherlands, she completed research fellowships at Columbia University’s Center for Science, Policy and Outcomes, and Harvard University’s Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs at the Kennedy School of Government. Aarti has combined this research trajectory with working outside of academia as well, including with the United Nations Development Programme in New York, Oxfam-Novib in the Hague, and Transparency International in Berlin.

•	Co-founder and co-coordinator, REDD@WUR network: an interdisciplinary network of over 80 researchers working at the interface of forest and climate research

profile_positions.description:
Cambridge Elements in Earth System Governance was launched in 2018 to provide authoritative and concise (20,000 – 30,000 words) analyses of the challenges of governing earth system transformations. It addresses governance processes and institutions at all levels of decision-making, from local to global and is interdisciplinary in scope. 
•	As series co-editor, responsible for securing diverse, timely and agenda-setting analyses from leading scholars in the field of global environmental/sustainability governance
•	Responsible for assessing suitability of submitted manuscripts to be sent out to review, organizing peer review and taking final decisions
profile_positions.title: Series Co-Editor, Cambridge Elements in Earth System Governance

profile_positions.description: Top ranking ISI journal in political science and environmental studies. Current functions include advising on articles to go out for review, proposing reviewers, recommending final decisions, co-selecting special issue topics, and co-selecting new Editorial Board members.
profile_positions.title: Associate Editor, Global Environmental Politics

profile_positions.description:
The Earth System Governance Research Alliance is one of the largest global research networks of social science researchers working on sustainability. It was launched in 2009, with annual conferences and other avenues for fostering inter-disciplinary and disciplinary collaboration and networking
•	As of 2018, the leadership of this network is undertaken by a newly-selected 11-member Scientific Steering Committee, including representatives from all geographical regions, who are collectively responsible for network strategy, development and activities
•	This includes oversight and strategic development of the network’s research centers, taskforces, and other institutionalized interactions, and advising on annual conferences
profile_positions.title: Member, Scientific Steering Committee, Earth System Governance Project

profile_positions.description:
An international group of 14 global governance experts, established by American University’s Forum for Climate Engineering Assessment (FCEA), to critically assess the governance challenges associated with solar radiation management technologies
•	As part of the AWG, identified and assessed (through twice-yearly meetings) the research and policy challenges relating to solar climate engineering governance
•	Collaborated in generating a consensus-based final assessment report of near-term governance challenges posed by research into solar radiation management technologies (http://ceassessment.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/10/AWG_FCEA_governing-solar-radiation-management.pdf)
•	Contributed to roll-out and dissemination of the report and related developments, including through media coverage, blog posts and launch events in the the UK and India
profile_positions.title: Member, Academic Working Group of Climate Engineering Governance

profile_positions.description:

A member of Lead Faculty of the Earth System Governance Research Alliance, a group of approx. 50 leading academics from diverse disciplines and focusing on various topics within global environmental governance, who provide strategic advice and undertake collaborative research-related and network-building activities on behalf of the Earth System Governance research alliance
